GameDBLocalizedString.Text: Actinic Keratosis
An actinic keratosis is a rough, scaly patch on the skin that develops from years of exposure to the sun.
Nodule on the skin
A small, shiny bump or nodule on the skin
Basal Cell Carcinoma detected
Testing has detected Basal Cell Carcinoma with no signs of metastasis.
Basal Cell Carcinoma detected
Testing has detected Basal Cell Carcinoma with no signs of metastasis.
Perineural invasion
Perineural invasion, abbreviated PNI, refers to the invasion of cancer to the space surrounding a nerve.
Basal Cell Carcinoma detected
Testing has detected Basal Cell Carcinoma with signs that it has spread to nearby lymph nodes and surrounding tissue.
Basal Cell Carcinoma detected
Testing has detected Basal Cell Carcinoma with signs that it is metastatic.
Metastatic cancer
Metastatic cancer is cancer that spreads from its site of origin to another part of the body.
Chronic wound
Chronic wounds are sores that don’t heal within about three months. They can start small and might scab over again and again, but they don’t get better.
Squamous Cell Carcinoma detected
Testing has detected Squamous Cell Carcinoma with no signs of metastasis.
Squamous Cell Carcinoma detected
Testing has detected Squamous Cell Carcinoma with no signs of metastasis.
Squamous Cell Carcinoma detected
Testing has detected Squamous Cell Carcinoma with signs that it has spread to nearby lymph nodes and surrounding tissue.
Squamous Cell Carcinoma detected
Testing has detected Squamous Cell Carcinoma with signs that it is metastatic.
Abnormal Mole
A mole with an uneven border, unusual color, or change in growth.
Melanoma detected
Testing has detected Melanoma with no signs that it is metastatic.
Melanoma detected
Testing has detected Melanoma with no signs that it is metastatic.
Melanoma detected
Testing has detected Melanoma with signs that it has spread to nearby lymph nodes and surrounding tissue.
Melanoma detected
Testing has detected Melanoma with signs that it is metastatic
High epinephrine levels
The patient has elevated blood levels of epinephrine (adrenaline). Adrenaline is normally produced by both the adrenal glands and a small number of neurons in the medulla oblongata.
High norepinephrine levels

The patient has elevated blood levels of norepinephrine (noradrenaline). Norepinephrine is a naturally occurring chemical in the body that acts as both a stress hormone and neurotransmitter. It's released into the blood as a stress hormone when the brain perceives that a stressful event has occurred.
Pheochromocytoma detected
Testing has detected Pheochromocytoma with evidence it is only localised.
Pheochromocytoma detected
Testing has detected Pheochromocytoma with evidence it is regional.
Pheochromocytoma detected
Testing has detected Pheochromocytoma with evidence it is metastatic.
Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer (NSCLC) detected
Testing has detected Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer with evidence it is only localised.
Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer (NSCLC) detected
Testing has detected Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer with evidence it is regional.
Seizures
A seizure is a sudden, uncontrolled electrical disturbance in the brain. It can cause changes in your behavior, movements or feelings, and in levels of consciousness.
Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer (NSCLC) detected
Testing has detected Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer with evidence it is metastatic.
Hemoptysis

Hemoptysis is the coughing up of blood or blood-stained mucus from the bronchi, larynx, trachea, or lungs. In other words, it is the airway bleeding. This can occur with lung cancer, infections such as tuberculosis, bronchitis, or pneumonia, and certain cardiovascular conditions.
Small Cell Lung Cancer (SCLC) detected
Testing has detected Small Cell Lung Cancer with evidence it is in limited state.
Small Cell Lung Cancer (SCLC) detected
Testing has detected Small Cell Lung Cancer with evidence it is in extensive state.
Postoperative Neuropathic Pain

Postoperative neuropathic pain (PONP) can develop if nerves were damaged during a surgery. Damaged nerves cannot correctly transmit signals from various parts of the body to the brain. Instead, these signals become exaggerated, causing chronic pain that may persist for months or even years.
Anaphylactic Shock
Anaphylactic shock is a rare but severe allergic reaction that can be deadly if you don't treat it right away. It's most often caused by an allergy to food, insect bites, or certain medications.
Colorectal Adenocarcinoma detected
Testing has detected Colorectal Adenocarcinoma with evidence it is only localised.
Colorectal Adenocarcinoma detected
Testing has detected Colorectal Adenocarcinoma with evidence it is regional.
Colorectal Adenocarcinoma detected
Testing has detected Colorectal Adenocarcinoma with evidence it is metastatic.
High carcinoembryonic antigen levels

The patient has elevated blood levels of carcinoembryonic antigen. A high level of CEA can be a sign of certain types of cancers. These include cancers of the colon and rectum, prostate, ovary, lung, thyroid, or liver. High CEA levels may also be a sign of some noncancerous conditions, such as cirrhosis, noncancerous breast disease, and emphysema.
Colorectal polyp

A polyp is a growth of tissue on the lining of the colon and rectum that projects into the intestines. People with colon polyps usually have no symptoms. Most colon polyps are harmless, though some types can become cancerous.
